pb.facs: The A.M.E. Zion quarterly review part 1.pdf

div2.p: tions. All enjoyed the rare treat but none more than Douglass himself.

Mrs. Josie D. Heard, who is acknowledge to be one of the best poets of the race, is to be congratulated, as well as Dr. W. H. Heard, her husband, on his recent appointment as Min- ister to Liberia. We have no doubt that she will adorn the position of Minister's wife, at a foreign court.

Mrs. Bishop C. R. Harris deserves to be congratulated on her splendid success in having her husband treated during his long illness. Her advice has been followed to the very letter throughout, and the bishop's great improvement, is due in large measure to her excellent care of him.
Mrs. Prof. C. H. Moore, of Greensboro, who had been quite ill for a long while, we are pleased to learn is quite completely restored to health, to the delight of her many friends.
Miss Maggie I. Hood, daughter of Bishop J. W. Hood, is teaching at Lancaster, S. C.

At the residence of Bishop Thomas H. Lomax, D. D., Bishop I. C. Clinton, D. D., officiating, just before the holidays, Miss Isadora Lomax, daughter of Bishop and Mrs. Lomax, was united in holy wedlock to Mr. W. B. Coles, formerly of South Carolina but now of Washington, D. C., in the presence of many friends. A grand collation followed.
